entity.name: `<datalist>`
entity.description: Method of providing a list of presets for a user to select in a form control, while still allowing custom options.
entity.descriptionClean: Method of providing a list of presets for a user to select in a form control, while still allowing custom options.

mdn.title: <datalist>: The HTML Data List element
mdn.summary: The <datalist> HTML element contains a set of <option> elements that represent the permissible or recommended options available to choose from within other controls.

example.codeHighlighted: <input name="country" list="countries"> <datalist id="countries"> <option>Afghanistan</option> ... </datalist>

webFeature.description_html: The <datalist> element sets recommended values for an <input> element. Browsers may show a dropdown menu of all values or match values as the user types.
webFeature.name: <datalist>

entity.name: `autocomplete` attribute
entity.description: Provide hints about what kind of information is expected, e.g. `name`, `honorific-prefix`, `tel`,  `cc-number` etc
entity.descriptionClean: Provide hints about what kind of information is expected, e.g. name, honorific-prefix, tel,  cc-number etc
entity.descriptionHtml: Provide hints about what kind of information is expected, e.g. name, honorific-prefix, tel, cc-number etc

mdn.title: HTML attribute: autocomplete
mdn.summary: The HTML autocomplete attribute lets web developers specify what if any permission the user agent has to provide automated assistance in filling out form field values, as well as guidance to the browser as to the type of information expected in the field.

example.codeHighlighted: <input name="address_firstline" autocomplete="billing street-address" />

webFeature.description_html: The capture HTML attribute for <input type="file"> elements allows the user to capture media using the device's camera or microphone.
webFeature.name: HTML media capture

entity.name: `input.showPicker()`
entity.description: Programmatically open the picker of form controls that have one (color pickers, date inputs etc).
entity.descriptionClean: Programmatically open the picker of form controls that have one (color pickers, date inputs etc).

mdn.title: HTMLInputElement: showPicker() method
mdn.summary: The HTMLInputElement.showPicker() method displays the browser picker for an input element.

example.codeHighlighted: <input id="dateInput" type="date"> <button onclick="dateInput.showPicker()">Select date</button>

webFeature.description_html: The showPicker() method for <input> elements shows the user interface for picking a value. For example, for <input type="date"> it shows the interface for picking a date.
webFeature.name: showPicker() for <input>

entity.name: FormData API
entity.description: API to more easily extract and manipulate form data values via JS
entity.descriptionClean: API to more easily extract and manipulate form data values via JS

mdn.title: FormData: FormData() constructor
mdn.summary: The FormData() constructor creates a new FormData object.

example.code:
let fd = new FormData(form);
let data = JSON.stringify(Object.fromEntries(fd));
example.codeHighlighted: let fd = new FormData(form); let data = JSON.stringify(Object.fromEntries(fd));

entity.name: Customizable Select
entity.description: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously `<selectlist>` and `<selectmenu>`.
entity.descriptionClean: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously <selectlist> and <selectmenu>.
entity.descriptionHtml: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously <selectlist> and <selectmenu>.

example.codeHighlighted: select, ::picker(select) { appearance: base-select; }

resources.title: The selectmenu HTML Tag | CSS-Tricks - CSS-Tricks
Advanced Form Control Styling With Selectmenu And Anchoring API — Smashing Magazine

webFeature.description_html: The <select> element's appearance, including the button, selected option, picker dropdown, and options, can be customized using CSS.
webFeature.name: Customizable <select>

entity.name: `contenteditable="plaintext-only"`
entity.description: Permits editing of the element's raw text, but not rich text formatting.
entity.descriptionClean: Permits editing of the element's raw text, but not rich text formatting.
entity.descriptionHtml: Permits editing of the element's raw text, but not rich text formatting.

mdn.title: HTML contenteditable global attribute
mdn.summary: The contenteditable global attribute is an enumerated attribute indicating if the element should be editable by the user. If so, the browser modifies its widget to allow editing.

example.codeHighlighted: <h2 class="title" contenteditable="plaintext-only"></h2>

webFeature.description_html: The contenteditable="plaintext-only" global HTML attribute allows the user to edit the content of an element, but prevents rich-text formatting.
webFeature.name: contenteditable="plaintext-only"

entity.name: `EditContext`
entity.description: The EditContext interface represents the text edit context of an element that was made editable by using the EditContext API.
entity.descriptionClean: The EditContext interface represents the text edit context of an element that was made editable by using the EditContext API.

mdn.title: EditContext
mdn.summary: The EditContext interface represents the text edit context of an element that was made editable by using the EditContext API.

example.codeHighlighted: const canvas = document.createElement("canvas"); const editContext = new EditContext(); canvas.editContext = editContext;

webFeature.description_html: The EditContext API allows you to build rich text editors that support advanced text input, such as Input Method Editor (IME) composition, an emoji picker, or other platform-specific editing UI.
webFeature.name: EditContext

entity.name: `caretPositionFromPoint`
entity.description: The caretPositionFromPoint() method returns the caret's character offset.
entity.descriptionClean: The caretPositionFromPoint() method returns the caret's character offset.
entity.descriptionHtml: The caretPositionFromPoint() method returns the caret's character offset.

example.codeHighlighted: const range = document.caretPositionFromPoint(e.clientX, e.clientY); const textNode = range.offsetNode; const offset = range.offset;

webFeature.description_html: The document.caretPositionFromPoint() method finds an insertion point, represented by a DOM node and an offset within that node, for given coordinates in the viewport.
webFeature.name: document.caretPositionFromPoint()

entity.name: `<dialog>`
entity.description: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
entity.descriptionClean: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.

mdn.title: <dialog>: The Dialog element
mdn.summary: The <dialog> HTML element represents a modal or non-modal dialog box or other interactive component, such as a dismissible alert, inspector, or subwindow.

example.code:
<dialog id="confirm">
	<form method="dialog">
		Are you sure?
		<button value="1">Yes</button>
		<button value="0">No</button>
	</form>
</dialog>
example.codeHighlighted: <dialog id="confirm"> <form method="dialog"> Are you sure? <button value="1">Yes</button> <button value="0">No</button> </form> </dialog>

webFeature.description_html: The <dialog> HTML element represents a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
webFeature.name: <dialog>

entity.name: `<details>` and `<summary>`
entity.description: A disclosure widget that can be toggled to hide or show content interactively.
entity.descriptionClean: A disclosure widget that can be toggled to hide or show content interactively.

mdn.title: <details>: The Details disclosure element
mdn.summary: The <details> HTML element creates a disclosure widget in which information is visible only when the widget is toggled into an open state. A summary or label must be provided using the <summary> element.

example.codeHighlighted: <details> <summary>Details</summary> Longer content </details>

webFeature.description_html: The <details> element is a disclosure widget which can be expanded to reveal additional content. When closed, only the nested <summary> element is visible.
webFeature.name: <details>

entity.name: `<details name>` (Exclusive Accordion)
entity.description: Group `<details>` elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionClean: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionHtml: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.

example.code:
<details open name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Main info</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
<details name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Style</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
example.codeHighlighted: <details open name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Main info</summary> <!-- controls --> </details> <details name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Style</summary> <!-- controls --> </details>

resources.title: Add name attribute for grouping details elements into an exclusive accordion by dbaron · Pull Request #9400 · whatwg/html · GitHub
Exclusive accordion (<details name="">) · Issue #866 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: Multiple <details> elements which use the same name attribute are mutually exclusive. When one member of the group is opened, all other members are closed.
webFeature.name: Mutually exclusive <details> elements

entity.name: `popover` attribute (Popover API)
entity.description: HTML syntax and JS API facilitating popovers such as overlays, popups, menus etc.
entity.descriptionClean: HTML syntax and JS API facilitating popovers such as overlays, popups, menus etc.

mdn.title: Popover API
mdn.summary: The Popover API provides developers with a standard, consistent, flexible mechanism for displaying popover content on top of other page content. Popover content can be controlled either using HTML attributes, or via JavaScript.

example.code: Popover content
example.codeHighlighted: <button popovertarget="foo">Toggle the popover</button> <div id="foo" popover>Popover content</div>

resources.title: The Popover API (previously Popup) · Issue #743 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: The popover HTML attribute creates an overlay to display content on top of other page content. Popovers can be shown declaratively using HTML, or using the showPopover() method.
webFeature.name: Popover

entity.name: `inert` attribute
entity.description: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.
entity.descriptionClean: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.

mdn.title: HTML inert global attribute
mdn.summary: The inert global attribute is a Boolean attribute indicating that the element and all of its flat tree descendants become inert. Modal <dialog>s generated with showModal() escape inertness, meaning that they don't inherit inertness from their ancestors, but can only be made inert by having the inert attribute explicitly set on themselves.

example.codeHighlighted: <div id=app inert class=loading> ... </div>

resources.title: The "inert" attribute is finally coming to the web | Stefan Judis Web Development

webFeature.description_html: The inert HTML attribute marks an element and its descendants as non-interactive. Inert elements don't get focus or fire click events.
webFeature.name: inert

entity.name: Clipboard API
entity.description: Provides the ability to respond to clipboard commands (cut, copy, and paste), as well as to asynchronously read from and write to the system clipboard.
entity.descriptionClean: Provides the ability to respond to clipboard commands (cut, copy, and paste), as well as to asynchronously read from and write to the system clipboard.

mdn.title: Clipboard API
mdn.summary: The Clipboard API provides the ability to respond to clipboard commands (cut, copy, and paste), as well as to asynchronously read from and write to the system clipboard.

webFeature.description_html: The navigator.clipboard API asynchronously reads and writes to the system clipboard.
webFeature.name: Async clipboard

entity.name: `loading="lazy"`
entity.description: Load certain resources only when needed.
entity.descriptionClean: Load certain resources only when needed.

mdn.title: Lazy loading
mdn.summary: Lazy loading is a strategy to identify resources as non-blocking (non-critical) and load these only when needed. It's a way to shorten the length of the critical rendering path, which translates into reduced page load times.

example.codeHighlighted: <img src="picture.jpg" loading="lazy" /> <iframe src="supplementary.html" loading="lazy"></iframe>

resources.title: Browser-level image lazy loading for the web

webFeature.description_html: The loading="lazy" attribute for <img> and <iframe> elements blocks loading the external resource until the user scrolls to that element's part of the page.
webFeature.name: Lazy-loading images and iframes

entity.name: `srcset` and `sizes` attributes
entity.description: Attributes that allow providing several source images with hints to help the browser pick the right one.
entity.descriptionClean: Attributes that allow providing several source images with hints to help the browser pick the right one.

mdn.title: : The Image Embed element
mdn.summary: The HTML element embeds an image into the document.

example.codeHighlighted: <img srcset="fairy-med.jpg 480w, fairy-large.jpg 800w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 480px, 800px" src="fairy-large.jpg" alt="Elva dressed as a fairy" />

webFeature.description_html: The imagesrcset and imagesizes attributes with the rel="preload" attribute for the <link> HTML element starts fetching responsive images before they're found in the body of the document.
webFeature.name: Preloading responsive images

entity.name: Resource Hints
entity.description:
Begin work on certain resources early to improve performance.
Syntax: `<link rel="pre* | dns-prefetch | modulepreload">`.
entity.descriptionClean: Begin work on certain resources early to improve performance.Syntax: <link rel="pre* | dns-prefetch | modulepreload">.
entity.descriptionHtml: Begin work on certain resources early to improve performance. Syntax: <link rel="pre* | dns-prefetch | modulepreload">.

mdn.title: Web performance resources
mdn.summary:
There are many reasons why your website should perform as well as possible.
Below is a quick review of best practices, tools, APIs with links to provide more information about each topic.

example.codeHighlighted: <link rel="preload" href="picture.jpg" /> <link rel="dns-prefetch" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/" />

resources.title: Understanding CSS preload and other resource hints - LogRocket Blog

entity.name: Content-Security Policy (CSP)
entity.description: A set of directives from a website to a browser, that helps to detect and mitigate XSS attacks.
entity.descriptionClean: A set of directives from a website to a browser, that helps to detect and mitigate XSS attacks.

mdn.title: Content Security Policy (CSP)
mdn.summary: Content Security Policy (CSP) is a feature that helps to prevent or minimize the risk of certain types of security threats. It consists of a series of instructions from a website to a browser, which instruct the browser to place restrictions on the things that the code comprising the site is allowed to do.

example.codeHighlighted: Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self';

webFeature.description_html: Content Security Policy (CSP) helps to mitigate certain security threats, including cross-site scripting (XSS) and clickjacking attacks. It consists of a set of directives from a website to a browser, which instruct the browser to restrict the things that the site is allowed to do.
webFeature.name: Content Security Policy (CSP)

entity.name: `fetchpriority` attribute
entity.description: Allows specifying a hint to help the browser prioritize fetching various resources.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows specifying a hint to help the browser prioritize fetching various resources.

mdn.title: HTMLImageElement: fetchPriority property
mdn.summary: The fetchPriority property of the HTMLImageElement interface represents a hint to the browser indicating how it should prioritize fetching a particular image relative to other images. It reflects the fetchpriority attribute of the corresponding element.

example.codeHighlighted: <img src="logo.svg" fetchpriority="high" />

resources.title: Priority Hints API · Issue #704 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub
Optimizing resource loading with the Fetch Priority API

webFeature.description_html: The fetch() priority option and the fetchpriority HTML attribute give hints to the browser about which requests to do before other requests of the same type.
webFeature.name: Fetch priority

entity.name: `blocking="render"`
entity.description: Block rendering (but not parsing) until certain resources have been loaded. Available on `<link>`, `<script>` and `<style>`.
entity.descriptionClean: Block rendering (but not parsing) until certain resources have been loaded. Available on <link>, <script> and <style>.
entity.descriptionHtml: Block rendering (but not parsing) until certain resources have been loaded. Available on <link>, <script> and <style>.

mdn.title: <script>: The Script element
mdn.summary: The <script> HTML element is used to embed executable code or data; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code. The <script> element can also be used with other languages, such as WebGL's GLSL shader programming language and JSON.

example.codeHighlighted: <script blocking="render" async src="async-script.js"></script>

resources.title: Review request on `blocking=render` attribute for scripts and stylesheets · Issue #727 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: The blocking="render" attribute for <link>, <script>, and <style> elements blocks rendering until the external script or stylesheet has been loaded. For <link rel="expect">, rendering is blocked until a specific element is in the DOM.
webFeature.name: blocking="render"

entity.name: `<model>` (Inline AR/VR/3D content)
entity.description: Allows embedding 3D models in HTML with built-in controls.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows embedding 3D models in HTML with built-in controls.

example.codeHighlighted: <model src="3d-assets/car.glb"></model>

resources.title: AR, VR, and a Model for 3D in HTML | CSS-Tricks - CSS-Tricks
Safari Technology Preview 137 Release Notes | Apple Developer Documentation

entity.name: `controlslist` attribute
entity.description: Prevent certain controls from appearing in the toolbar of a media element.
entity.descriptionClean: Prevent certain controls from appearing in the toolbar of a media element.

mdn.title: HTMLMediaElement: controlsList property
mdn.summary:
The controlsList property of the
HTMLMediaElement interface returns a DOMTokenList that helps the user
agent select what controls to show on the media element whenever the user agent shows
its own set of controls. The DOMTokenList takes one or more of three possible values:
nodownload, nofullscreen, and noremoteplayback.

example.codeHighlighted: <video src="fun.mp4" controlslist="nodownload"></video>

webFeature.description_html: The controlslist attribute for <audio> or <video> hides parts of the browser's built-in controls. For example, controlslist="nofullscreen" removes the button to play the video in fullscreen.
webFeature.name: controlslist

entity.name: CSS Custom Highlight API
entity.description: Provides a mechanism for styling arbitrary text ranges on a document by using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to style them.
entity.descriptionClean: Provides a mechanism for styling arbitrary text ranges on a document by using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to style them.

mdn.title: CSS Custom Highlight API
mdn.summary: The CSS Custom Highlight API provides a mechanism for styling arbitrary text ranges on a document by using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to style them.

example.codeHighlighted: // css ::highlight(my-custom-highlight) { background-color: blue; } // js const parentNode = document.getElementById("foo"); const range1 = new Range(); range1.setStart(parentNode, 10); range1.setEnd(parentNode, 20); const highlight = new Highlight(range1); CSS.highlights.set("my-custom-highlight", highlight);

webFeature.description_html: Custom highlights style arbitrary text ranges, without adding extra elements to the DOM.
webFeature.name: Custom highlights

entity.name: `setHtmlUnsafe()`
entity.description: Used to parse a string of HTML into a DocumentFragment, which then replaces the element's subtree in the DOM.
entity.descriptionClean: Used to parse a string of HTML into a DocumentFragment, which then replaces the element's subtree in the DOM.
entity.descriptionHtml: Used to parse a string of HTML into a DocumentFragment, which then replaces the element's subtree in the DOM.

mdn.title: Element: setHTMLUnsafe() method
mdn.summary: The setHTMLUnsafe() method of the Element interface is used to parse HTML input into a DocumentFragment, optionally filtering out unwanted elements and attributes, and those that don't belong in the context, and then using it to replace the element's subtree in the DOM.

example.code:
const value = "

This is a string of text

"; document.getElementById("target").setHTMLUnsafe(value);
example.codeHighlighted: const value = "<p>This is a string of text</p>"; document.getElementById("target").setHTMLUnsafe(value);

webFeature.description_html: The Document.parseHTMLUnsafe() static method parses HTML into a DOM tree, while the setHTMLUnsafe() method of Element and ShadowRoot parses and inserts HTML into an existing tree. No sanitization applies to these methods, so never call them with user-provided HTML strings.
webFeature.name: Unsanitized HTML parsing methods

entity.name: `parseHtmlUnsafe()`
entity.description: Used to parse a string of HTML, which may contain declarative shadow roots, in order to create a new Document instance.
entity.descriptionClean: Used to parse a string of HTML, which may contain declarative shadow roots, in order to create a new Document instance.

mdn.title: Document: parseHTMLUnsafe() static method
mdn.summary: The parseHTMLUnsafe() static method of the Document object is used to parse HTML input, optionally filtering unwanted HTML elements and attributes, in order to create a new Document instance.

example.codeHighlighted: Document.parseHTMLUnsafe(input)

entity.name: `Intl.Segmenter` API
entity.description: Language-sensitive segmentation of text into graphemes, words or sentences.
entity.descriptionClean: Language-sensitive segmentation of text into graphemes, words or sentences.

mdn.title: Intl.Segmenter
mdn.summary: The Intl.Segmenter object enables locale-sensitive text segmentation, enabling you to get meaningful items (graphemes, words or sentences) from a string.

example.codeHighlighted: const segmenterFr = new Intl.Segmenter("fr", { granularity: "word" }); const string1 = "Que ma joie demeure"; const iterator1 = segmenterFr.segment(string1)[Symbol.iterator](); console.log(iterator1.next().value.segment); // Expected output: 'Que' console.log(iterator1.next().value.segment); // Expected output: ' '

webFeature.description_html: The Intl.Segmenter API creates a locale-aware text splitter that can separate a string into meaningful graphemes, words, or sentences.
webFeature.name: Intl.Segmenter

entity.name: `<template>`
entity.description: A mechanism for holding HTML that is not to be rendered immediately but may be utilized later via JS.
entity.descriptionClean: A mechanism for holding HTML that is not to be rendered immediately but may be utilized later via JS.

mdn.title: <template>: The Content Template element
mdn.summary: The <template> HTML element serves as a mechanism for holding HTML fragments, which can either be used later via JavaScript or generated immediately into shadow DOM.

example.codeHighlighted: <template id="counter"> <div class="counter">Clicked {{ times }} times</div> </template>

webFeature.description_html: The <template> HTML element holds HTML fragments which you can clone and insert into the document using JavaScript.
webFeature.name: <template>

entity.name: Using Custom Elements
entity.description: Using custom elements, that you or someone else defined.
entity.descriptionClean: Using custom elements, that you or someone else defined.

mdn.title: Using custom elements
mdn.summary: One of the key features of web components is the ability to create custom elements: that is, HTML elements whose behavior is defined by the web developer, that extend the set of elements available in the browser.

example.codeHighlighted: <my-switch start="On" end="Off">Wi-Fi</my-switch>

entity.name: Defining Custom Elements
entity.description: Defining custom elements for use by others.
entity.descriptionClean: Defining custom elements for use by others.

mdn.title: CustomElementRegistry: define() method
mdn.summary: The define() method of the CustomElementRegistry interface adds a definition for a custom element to the custom element registry, mapping its name to the constructor which will be used to create it.

example.code:
class MyElement extends HTMLElement { … }
customElements.define("my-element", MyElement);
example.codeHighlighted: class MyElement extends HTMLElement { … } customElements.define("my-element", MyElement);

entity.name: Scoped Custom Element Registries
entity.description: Allow multiple custom element definitions for a single tag name to exist within a page.
entity.descriptionClean: Allow multiple custom element definitions for a single tag name to exist within a page.

example.code:
const registry = new CustomElementRegistry();
registry.define('sub-element', SubElement);
example.codeHighlighted: const registry = new CustomElementRegistry(); registry.define('sub-element', SubElement);

entity.name: Shadow DOM
entity.description: Encapsulate elements not visible from the outside, and style them with CSS not affecting the rest of the page.
entity.descriptionClean: Encapsulate elements not visible from the outside, and style them with CSS not affecting the rest of the page.

mdn.title: Using shadow DOM
mdn.summary: An important aspect of custom elements is encapsulation, because a custom element, by definition, is a piece of reusable functionality: it might be dropped into any web page and be expected to work. So it's important that code running in the page should not be able to accidentally break a custom element by modifying its internal implementation. Shadow DOM enables you to attach a DOM tree to an element, and have the internals of this tree hidden from JavaScript and CSS running in the page.

example.codeHighlighted: this.shadowRoot = this.attachShadow({mode: "open"});

webFeature.description_html: Shadow DOM allows you to attach encapsulated "shadow" DOM trees to elements. A shadow DOM tree is a separate component, isolated from the scripts and styles in other parts of the document. This is a part of Web Components.
webFeature.name: Shadow DOM

entity.name: Declarative Shadow DOM
entity.description: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.
entity.descriptionClean: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.

example.codeHighlighted: <host-element> <template shadowrootmode="open"> <!-- Shadow content --> </template> </host-element>

resources.title: GitHub - mfreed7/declarative-shadow-dom: Declarative Shadow DOM feature development

webFeature.description_html: The shadowrootmode attribute on <template> creates a shadow root without the use of JavaScript. It is a declarative alternative to the attachShadow() method.
webFeature.name: Declarative shadow DOM

entity.name: `slot` attribute
entity.description: Replacing predefined parts of a component UI with your own elements.
entity.descriptionClean: Replacing predefined parts of a component UI with your own elements.

mdn.title: HTML slot global attribute
mdn.summary: The slot global attribute assigns a slot in a shadow DOM shadow tree to an element: An element with a slot attribute is assigned to the slot created by the <slot> element whose name attribute's value matches that slot attribute's value. You can have multiple elements assigned to the same slot by using the same slot name. Elements without a slot attribute are assigned to the unnamed slot, if one exists.

example.codeHighlighted: <my-switch> Wi-Fi <i slot="start" class="icon-on">On</i> <i slot="end" class="icon-off">Off</i> </my-switch>

webFeature.description_html: The <slot> HTML element is a placeholder inside a web component where consumers of the component can insert their own markup.
webFeature.name: <slot>

entity.name: `slotAssignment: "manual"` (Imperative slot assignment)
entity.description: A way to assign elements to slots manually via JS, so that slot assignment does not have to be managed by the component consumers.
entity.descriptionClean: A way to assign elements to slots manually via JS, so that slot assignment does not have to be managed by the component consumers.

mdn.title: HTMLSlotElement: assign() method
mdn.summary: The assign() method of the HTMLSlotElement interface sets the slot's manually assigned nodes to an ordered set of slottables. The manually assigned nodes set is initially empty until nodes are assigned using assign().

example.codeHighlighted: this.attachShadow({mode: "open", slotAssignment: "manual" }); let headerSlot = this.shadowRoot.querySelector("slot[name=header]"); let header = this.querySelector("header"); if (header) headerSlot.assign(header);

webFeature.description_html: The assign() method for <slot> elements assigns nodes to the slot, as an alternative to using the slot and name HTML attributes. The nodes must be children of a shadow host and the shadow root must be created with the slotAssignment set to "manual". Also known as manual slot assignment.
webFeature.name: Imperative slot assignment

entity.name: `ElementInternals`
entity.description: Assign hidden semantics to custom elements, facilitating accessibility and allowing them to participate fully in forms.
entity.descriptionClean: Assign hidden semantics to custom elements, facilitating accessibility and allowing them to participate fully in forms.

mdn.title: ElementInternals
mdn.summary: The ElementInternals interface of the Document Object Model gives web developers a way to allow custom elements to fully participate in HTML forms. It provides utilities for working with these elements in the same way you would work with any standard HTML form element, and also exposes the Accessibility Object Model to the element.

example.codeHighlighted: this._internals = this.attachInternals(); this._internals.role = "progressbar";

webFeature.description_html: Custom elements may act like built-in form elements, via the the attachInternals() method of HTMLElement and the ElementInternals API.
webFeature.name: Form-associated custom elements

entity.name: DOM Parts
entity.description: A cacheable representation of a part of the DOM that can be updated performantly.
entity.descriptionClean: A cacheable representation of a part of the DOM that can be updated performantly.

entity.name: HTML Modules
entity.description: Import HTML files via JS imports and access their elements and JS exports.
entity.descriptionClean: Import HTML files via JS imports and access their elements and JS exports.

example.code:
<script type="module">
	import { TabList } from "./tablist.html" with { type: 'html' };
	customElements.define("tab-list", TabList);
</script>
example.codeHighlighted: <script type="module"> import { TabList } from "./tablist.html" with { type: 'html' }; customElements.define("tab-list", TabList); </script>

entity.name: Landmark elements
entity.description: `<main>`, `<nav>`, `<aside>`, `<header>`, `<footer>`, `<section>`
entity.descriptionClean: <main>, <nav>, <aside>, <header>, <footer>, <section>

resources.title: HTML5 landmark elements are used to improve navigation

entity.name: `tabindex` attribute
entity.description: Make HTML elements focusable, allow or prevent them from being sequentially focusable.
entity.descriptionClean: Make HTML elements focusable, allow or prevent them from being sequentially focusable.

mdn.title: HTML tabindex global attribute
mdn.summary: The tabindex global attribute allows developers to make HTML elements focusable, allow or prevent them from being sequentially focusable (usually with the Tab key, hence the name) and determine their relative ordering for sequential focus navigation.

example.codeHighlighted: <div role="button" tabindex="0">I’m Tabbable</div>

webFeature.description_html: The tabindex HTML attribute make an element focusable, and sets the element's relative ordering for sequential focus navigation.
webFeature.name: tabindex

entity.name: `focusgroup` attribute
entity.description: Facilitate keyboard focus navigation using the keyboard arrow keys among a set of focusable elements.
entity.descriptionClean: Facilitate keyboard focus navigation using the keyboard arrow keys among a set of focusable elements.

example.codeHighlighted: <div focusgroup="wrap horizontal"> <!-- child elements --> </div>

resources.title: 1286127 -       chromium -      An open-source project to help move the web forward. -     Monorail

entity.name: `<search>`
entity.description: Semantic element for wrapping search UI.
entity.descriptionClean: Semantic element for wrapping search UI.

mdn.title: <search>: The generic search element
mdn.summary: The <search> HTML element is a container representing the parts of the document or application with form controls or other content related to performing a search or filtering operation. The <search> element semantically identifies the purpose of the element's contents as having search or filtering capabilities. The search or filtering functionality can be for the website or application, the current web page or document, or the entire Internet or subsection thereof.

example.codeHighlighted: <search> <form action="search.php"> <label>Find: <input name="q" type="search"></label> <button>Go!</button> </form> </search>

webFeature.description_html: The <search> HTML element is a container that represents the parts of the web page with search functionality.
webFeature.name: <search>

entity.name: File System Access API
entity.description: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.
entity.descriptionClean: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.
entity.descriptionHtml: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.

mdn.title: File System API
mdn.summary: The File System API — with extensions provided via the File System Access API to access files on the device file system — allows read, write and file management capabilities.

example.codeHighlighted: const handle = await window.showSaveFilePicker(); const writable = await handle.createWritable(); await writable.write("Hello, world!"); await writable.close();

webFeature.description_html: The showOpenFilePicker(), showDirectoryPicker(), and showSaveFilePicker() methods request access to files and directories on the user's device and returns a handle for reading and writing to them.
webFeature.name: File system access

entity.name: Badging API
entity.description: Set a badge on the web application’s icon to notify about updated state in a less intrusive, persistent way.
entity.descriptionClean: Set a badge on the web application’s icon to notify about updated state in a less intrusive, persistent way.

mdn.title: Badging API
mdn.summary: The Badging API gives web developers a method of setting a badge on a document or application, to act as a notification that state has changed without displaying a more distracting notification. A common use case for this would be an application with a messaging feature displaying a badge on the app icon to show that new messages have arrived.

example.codeHighlighted: navigator.setAppBadge(unreadCount)

resources.title: Badging for app icons - Chrome Developers

entity.name: Web Share API
entity.description: Exposes a mechanism for sharing content to various user-selected targets.
entity.descriptionClean: Exposes a mechanism for sharing content to various user-selected targets.

mdn.title: Web Share API
mdn.summary: The Web Share API provides a mechanism for sharing text, links, files, and other content to an arbitrary share target selected by the user.

example.codeHighlighted: navigator.share(shareData)

resources.title: Integrate with the OS sharing UI with the Web Share API

webFeature.description_html: The navigator.share() method invokes the device's native sharing mechanism and passes text, links, files, and other content to share targets.
webFeature.name: navigator.share()

entity.name: Launch Handler API
entity.description: Allows PWAs to control how they are launched, e.g. in a new window or tab.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows PWAs to control how they are launched, e.g. in a new window or tab.

mdn.title: launch_handler
mdn.summary: The launch_handler member defines values that control the launch of a web application. Currently it can only contain a single value, client_mode, which specifies the context in which the app should be loaded when launched. For example, in an existing web app client containing an instance of the app, or in a new web app client. This leaves scope for more launch_handler values to be defined in the future.

example.label: manifest.json
example.codeHighlighted: "launch_handler": {"client_mode": "navigate-new"}

resources.title: Launch Handler API: Control how your app is launched.

entity.name: `file_handlers` manifest field
entity.description: Allows PWAs to register themselves as handlers for certain file types.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows PWAs to register themselves as handlers for certain file types.

mdn.title: file_handlers
mdn.summary: The file_handlers member specifies an array of objects representing the types of files an installed progressive web app (PWA) can handle.

example.label: manifest.json
example.codeHighlighted: "file_handlers": [{ "action": "/open-file", "accept": { "image/svg+xml": ".svg", "image/png": ".png" } }]

resources.title: File Handling API: Register your PWA as a handler for file types.

webFeature.description_html: The file_handlers web app manifest member registers an installed web app as a handler for files with specific file extensions or MIME types.
webFeature.name: File handlers

entity.name: Window Controls Overlay API
entity.description: Allows PWAs to display custom content over the title bar area, whose controls become an overlay.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows PWAs to display custom content over the title bar area, whose controls become an overlay.

mdn.title: Window Controls Overlay API
mdn.summary:
The Window Controls Overlay API gives Progressive Web Apps installed on desktop operating systems the ability to hide the default window title bar and display their own content
over the full surface area of the app window, turning the control buttons (maximize, minimize, and close) into an overlay.

example.label: manifest.json
example.codeHighlighted: "display_override": ["window-controls-overlay"]

resources.title: Customize the window controls overlay of your PWA's title bar

webFeature.description_html: The display_override:\ ["window-controls-overlay"] web application manifest member shows content in the title bar area of a progressive web app that is installed on a desktop device.
webFeature.name: Window Controls Overlay

entity.name: Isolated Web Apps
entity.description: Native-like packaging, permissions and signed updates for PWAs.
entity.descriptionClean: Native-like packaging, permissions and signed updates for PWAs.

example.label: URL
example.codeHighlighted: isolated-app://4tkr2qbhf7rlz2a3wo3rh4wqaaic/index.html

resources.title: GitHub - WICG/isolated-web-apps: Repository for explainers and other documents related to the Isolated Web Apps proposal.
